title: KSR Today : Moving on from 2022 , Kentucky - Louisville and the Music City Bowl
body_text:
KSR Today: Moving on from 2022, Kentucky-Louisville and the Music City Bowl
Good morning and good luck navigating this first Monday morning of the new year. I hope your 2023 is off to a great start and your resolutions aren’t already broken.
Over here at KSR HQ, a double espresso shot with a side of black coffee is fueling the early start to today as we close the book on the busy weekend that included Saturday’s noon doubleheader, plus all of the other New Year’s weekend excitement. Of course, the highlight of the holiday was Kentucky Basketball drilling rival Louisville in Rupp Arena by 22 points, so we will start there with more basketball talk in this morning’s recap of things to know and what’s head moving further into 2023.
Kentucky Basketball to host LSU tomorrow; will preview the game today
Coming up later this morning, someone from Kentucky Basketball will hold a press conference to preview the next game on the schedule, tomorrow night’s SEC home opener versus LSU. The Wildcats will host the Tigers at 8 pm Tuesday night and today John Calipari (or one of his assistants or two of his players) will fulfill the media obligation by taking questions about the new opponent and the one Kentucky beat by 22 two days ago.
As always, Kentucky-Sports-Radio-dot-com is the place to be for complete coverage of that conversation. We’ll have the video and stories from the Q&A beginning around noon, so check back to learn more about Kentucky’s mindset heading into a new game.
More from Kentucky-Louisville
In case you missed it, here are KSR’s top stories and links following the win over the Cards on Saturday:
— WATCH: John Calipari’s Post-Louisville Game Press Conference
— WATCH: Kentucky players breakdown blowout win over Louisville
— KSR’s takeaways from Kentucky’s blowout win over Louisville
— Postgame stats and notes from Kentucky’s win over Louisville
— Kenny Payne says Kentucky is “one of the best teams in the country”
— John Calipari takes ownership of Kentucky’s struggles so far
— Jacob Toppin dug himself out of rock bottom ahead of breakthrough vs. Louisville
— John Calipari wants Kentucky to play “deliberate” basketball
L’s Down.
A new AP poll is on the way
Later today, the Associated Press will update its Top 25 for college basketball to reveal a new ranking of your Kentucky Wildcats. Currently, Kentucky is 19th in the AP and 17th in the Coaches Poll, but those numbers may change with today’s reshuffle of the order.
Expect a change near the top of the new poll after No. 2 UConn suffered its first loss of the season to Xavier, leaving No. 1 Purdue as the only unbeaten team in the rankings.
Kentucky up six places in the new NET Rankings
In the NCAA’s NET rankings, Kentucky moved from 47th to 41st in the new update that reflects the weekend’s results in college basketball. Kentucky is still without a Quad 1 win (0-3), but Michigan’s 21-spot move back into the Top 100 gave Kentucky a second Quad 2 win (2-1) for its resume.

The Cats’ next opponent, LSU, moved from 76th to 75th in the new Jan. 1 update to the NET.
Kentucky Women’s Basketball lost another one
At Memorial Coliseum, Kentucky Women’s Basketball lost its first game of the new year with a 21-point loss at the hands of 24th-ranked Arkansas on Sunday. The newly-engaged Blair Green scored 14 points to lead the Wildcats but the team still came up shy of keeping up with the Razorbacks in the 71-50 defeat in the Wildcats’ SEC home opener. Kentucky is now 0-2 in conference play and 8-6 on the season as a whole.
Kentucky has another opportunity to earn the first SEC win when the team travels to Athens to play Georgia this Thursday evening. Georgia plays at South Carolina tonight.
Revisit Kentucky Football’s loss in the Music City Bowl
Kentucky Football’s season ended Saturday with a disappointing loss to Iowa in the Music City Bowl. If you’re interested in learning more about that game, here’s all of KSR’s postgame coverage about the bowl game defeat.
— WATCH: Mark Stoops, Kentucky Players’ Post-Music City Bowl Press Conference
— Six Things Mark Stoops Said After The Loss
— Iowa’s defense, special teams dominate Kentucky in Music City Bowl
— Future is Bright for Kentucky Defense After Excellent Music City Bowl
— Three Plays: Complementary football beats Kentucky
— Destin Wade “Manned Up” in Difficult Situation
— Kentucky vs. Iowa After Action Review
We have four bowl games to watch today
Bowl season didn’t end with Ohio State’s shanked field goal Saturday night because there are still four more bowls to watch before the national championship is decided a week from tonight. Today, we have the last four bowls to enjoy with the first kicking off at noon to get the party started:
— Noon (ESPN2) // Mississippi State vs. Ilinois // ReliaQuest Bowl
— 1 p.m. (ABC) // LSU vs. Purdue // Cheez-It Citrus Bowl
— 1 p.m. (ESPN) // No. 10 USC vs. No. 16 Tulane // Goodyear Cotton Bowl Classic
— 5 p.m. (ESPN) // No. 8 Utah vs. No. 11 Penn State // Rose Bowl
Today’s KSR radio crew is working on a company holiday
Monday is a company holiday for most of iHeart Radio but Kentucky Sports Radio will clock in at 10 a.m. because the weekend was too busy to ignore. Matt Jones, Ryan Lemond, and I will be at KSBar and Grille for two hours of talk about the Kentucky Wildcats while Shannon The Dude keeps things moving from the Louisville studio.
So tune in for our thoughts on Kentucky-Louisville, the Music City Bowl, and more.
